data.title: Authors and Illustrators
data.text:
Peter Abraham

10. Richter, Karin. "Peter Abraham: Der Affenstern." Weimarer Beitrage: Zeitschrift für Literaturwissenschaft, Asthetik und Kulturtheorie 33.3 (1987): 470-77. [Not seen; MLA]

Richard Adams

11. ———. "To the Order of Two Little Girls: The Oral and Written Versions of Watership Down." Otten 115-22. [Based on an 1987 interview with Otten. Most of the material will be familiar to students of Adams, but there is some interesting new information about his vision of himself as the equivalent of the Greek chorus, about his treatment of death, and about the controversial quotations at the head of each chapter.]

12. Schmoll, Edward A. "Homeric Reminiscence in Watership Down." Classical and Modern Literature 10.1 (Fall 1989): 21-26. [Adds more data in support of Kenneth Kitchell's suggestion that WD is a worthy successor to ancient epic in "The Shrinking of the Epic Hero: From Homer to Richard Adams's Watership Down," Classical and Modem Literature 7 (1986): 13-30.]

Aelfric

13. Green, Eugene A. "Aelfric the Catechist." De Ore Domini: Preacher and Word in the Middle Ages. Studies in Medieval Culture XXVII. Medieval Institute Publications. Kalamazoo: Western Michigan University, 1989.

Aesop

14. Herman, Gertrude. "A Picture is Worth Several Hundred Words." Horn Book 65 (July-August 1989): 522-23. [Analyzes Wendy Watson's New Mexico-style illustrations for John Bierhorst's retelling of a sixteenth-century Aztec adaptation of Aesop, Doctor Coyote: A Native American's Aesop's Fables.] L.H.

15. The Medici Aesop: Spencer Ms. 50. Trans. Bernard McTigue. Intro. Everett Fahy. New York: Harry N. Abrahms, 1989. 175 p, illus. [A late 15th century collection of the fables in Greek with witty, almost cartoon-like, illustrations. Fahy surmises that it was meant to help a Florentine boy, the son of Lorenzo de Medici, to learn Greek. "A gorgeous book," D.J.R. Bruckner, New York Times Book Review, Nov., 1989.]

Janet and Allan Ahlberg.

16. De Groff, Linda. "Readers Theatre with The Jolly Postman." CLA Bulletin 15.2 (Summer 1989): 6-7. [Outlines a plan for adapting The Jolly Postman for readers' theater.] L.H.

Joan Aiken

17. ———. "Plot and Character in Suspense Fiction." The Writer May 1989: 9-13. [How to do it.]

18. Ross, Anna. "Profile: Joan Aiken." Language Arts 66.7 (1989): 784-90. [Outline of career and work based on a visit to her in Sussex.] E.B.

See also Canon: McGillis

Louisa May Alcott

19. Clark, Beverly Lyon. "A Portrait of the Artist as a Little Woman." CL 17 (1989): 81-97. [Argues that Alcott sees art as dangerous and devalues writing: "in her books as in her life the greatest good was not individual rights and self-fulfillment but loyalty and service to the family; she was a 'domestic feminist.'"]

20. Estes, Angela M. and Kathleen M. Lant. "Dismembering the Text: The Horror of Louisa May Alcott's Little Women." CL 17 (1989): 98-123. [Goes beyond the ambivalence noted by earlier critics to examine the "covert manipulation of the text by Alcott in order to disguise the fate of her experimental, self-reliant heroine," a fate that is not only self-mutilation but a living death.]

21. MacDonald, Ruth K. "Louisa May Alcott 1832-1888." Bingham 1-6. [Life; discussion of early works for adults and Little Women (1868), Good Wives (1869, now pub. as part II of Little Women), Little Men (1871), Jo's Boys (1886), An Old-Fashioned Girl (1870), Eight Cousins (1875), Rose in Bloom (1876), Under the Lilacs (1878), Jack and Jill (1880), and a posthumous collection of stories for teenage girls, A Garland for Girls (1888).]

22. Mills, Claudia. "Choosing a Way of Life: Eight Cousins and Six to Sixteen." CLAQ 14.2 (Summer 1989): 71-75. [Novels by the American Alcott and the English Ewing, both published in 1875 and treating the same theme, promote roughly the same ideas about raising and educating children: a qualified feminism but one which values the traditional home-making skills; a distrust of traditional girls...
